resources.string: WARNING:\nGadgetbridge is not found!\nClick DOWNLOAD to install it!

Your resting heart rate is the heart pumping the lowest amount of blood you need when you’re not exercising.\n\nIf you’re sitting or lying and you’re calm, relaxed and aren’t ill, your heart rate is normally between 60 and 100 (beats per min).

"Blood pressure is the force of blood pushing against blood vessel walls. It is measured in millimeters of mercury (mmHg).\n\nSystolic BP (the top) is the pressure when the heart beats. Diastolic BP (the bottom) is the pressure when the heart rests between beats."

Normal blood pressure is below 120/80 mm Hg.

If you’re an adult and your systolic pressure is 120 to 139, and your diastolic pressure is 80 to 89, you have pre-hypertension.

Pre-hypertension is blood pressure that is slightly higher than normal. Pre-hypertension increases the risk that you will develop chronic, or long-lasting, high blood pressure in the future.

The health record list shows all the data from smart devices, even those that are not correctly collected (e.g. when the band is not worn). Therefore, some data that deviates too much may also be marked as abnormal health data (e.g. -1 or 255). When you select chart view, these data that deviate too much are filtered out to show trends more reasonably.\n\nLegend of list view:
Are you sure to delete all archived messages? This operation is not revertible!

High blood pressure can burst or block arteries that supply blood and oxygen to the brain, causing a stroke. Stroke can cause serious disabilities in speech, movement, and other basic activities, and a stroke can kill you.
High blood pressure can harden your arteries, which decreases the flow of blood and oxygen to your heart and lead to multiple kinds of heart diseases.
High blood pressure can cause chest pain, which also called angina. If you often feel chest pain and your blood pressure exceeds hypertension limits, you should see a doctor.
High blood pressure can cause heart attack. Most heart attacks involve discomfort in the center or left side of the chest that lasts for more than a few minutes, or that goes away and comes back.

High blood pressure can cause heart failure. Common symptoms of heart failure include: 1.Shortness of breath during daily activities; 2.Having trouble breathing when lying down; 3.Generally feeling tired or weak.

High level of sodium(salt) intake contributes to hypertension. You should change to healthy diet which is: 1.Low in salt (sodium), total fat, saturated fat, and cholesterol; 2.High in fresh fruits and vegetables.
An active lifestyle helps to reduce hypertension. Try avoid obesity and a sedentary lifestyle by taking a brisk 10-minute walk 3 times a day 5 days a week.
Do not smoke. If you smoke, quit as soon as possible.
Do not drink excessively. Limit your drinking to two drink for man or one drink for woman.
Track your heart pressure data and abnormal symptoms each day. If you have conditions of heart failure or heart attack, please see your doctor immediately.
Your recent blood pressure is higher than the limit of hypertension.
Your recent blood pressure is higher than the limit of pre-hypertension.
If you are exercising or the blood pressure is recorded when you are not relaxed, you may ignore this message. You can find its archive later in the application.
Click here to see what you should do to lower your pressure.
Hypertension can damage your health in many ways. Click to see detail.
There is a strong positive association between racing heart rate and ischemic cardiac disease and sudden heart death.
Relatively high heart rate is often found with hypertension, atherosclerosis and overweight.
High heart rate is related to multiple cardiac diseases. The increase of heart rate may increase the risk in heart failure and coronary artery disease.
Low heart rate may cause insufficient blood supply in your heart. Usual symptoms include chest tightness, headache, dizziness and even Loss of consciousness.
You should ensure enough sleeping time to improve heart rate condition. For adults, we recommend at least 8 hours of sleep per day.
You should keep a healthy lifestyle. Ensure adequate daily exercise. Do not smoke and drink excessively.
Keep the air clean. Avoid exposure to tobacco smoke and stop outdoor activities when the air condition is bad.
There is no optimal heart rate for individuals. If you have symptoms listed above, we encourage you to discuss with your doctor.
Your heart is pumping faster than normal
Your heart is pumping slower than normal
Your recent heart rate is higher than 100 beats per minute. Click here to see detail.
Your recent heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute. Click here to see detail.
If you are exercising or the heart rate is recorded when you are not resting, you may ignore this message. You can find its archive later in the application.
If you have any listed symptoms or other uncomfortable feelings, we recommend you to contact your doctor.
